metadata.title: A novel low-temperature Fe-Fe double-atom catalyst for a “fast SCR” reaction

North China Electric Power University, Baoding, Hebei 071003, China. Department of Power Engineering North China Electric Power University Baoding Hebei 071003 China Theoretically designing a catalyst with high catalytic activity for ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) reaction at low temperature to guide the subsequent experimental synthesis, which is of great significance for controlling the emission of NO x . Herein, we examine for the first time Fe2-N6 catalysts as candidates for this application at a theoretical level. The adsorption behavior of various gases, catalytic mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction, and turnover frequency were analyzed using density functional theory calculations (DFT) and microkinetic modeling. We found that a “fast SCR” reaction is the dominant path of the NH3-SCR reaction. The energy barrier for the rate-determining step (HONO formation) is 1.00 eV, much lower than that of other SCR catalysts. In addition, the Fe2-N6 catalyst exhibits outstanding low-temperature activities in the temperature window from 300 to 500 K. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3 selective catalytic reduction Double-atom catalyst Density functional theory calculations Microkinetic modeling Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) are the primary atmospheric pollutant due to their contribution to acid rain, the greenhouse effect, photochemical smog, and smog [1]. During the past years, researchers have studied and developed several technologies to control NO x emissions. Among a variety of options, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) process with NH3 as a reductant is considered as the most efficient and practical method [2]. The essence of NH3-SCR is a redox reaction to covert NO to N2, which includes two principal pathways as follows: 4NH3 + 4NO + O2 → 4N2 + 6H2O 2NH3 + NO + NO2 → 2N2 + 3H2O The first reaction is usually denoted as the “standard SCR”. The reaction process involving an equimolar mixture of NO and NO2 is expressed as the “fast SCR”, whose reaction rate is ∼10 times faster than the first one [3]. Coal-fired power plant flue gas contains a considerable part of O2, NO, NO2, and other components. Iwasaki and Shinjoh [4] studied the NOx conversion on Fe/zeolite and found that although the NO2/NOx ratio was changed, the NOx conversion rate of fast SCR reaction was still higher than that of standard SCR reaction. In addition, Ciardelli et al. [5] have shown that fast SCR is still highly reactive at low temperatures, whether it is NO overdose or NO2 overdose. So far, the most widely used commercial catalysts are vanadium-titanium-based metal oxides [6]. However, due to shift to renewable energy, power plants are increasingly inclined to operate at low load. Take a 300 MW unit for example, when the load of a 300 MW unit is reduced by 75%, the SCR inlet flue gas temperature unit will drop to as low as 275 °C, making the catalysts fail to work in their optimal temperature window (300–400 °C) [7]. Additionally, the toxicity of V2O5 species leads to difficulty in handling and disposal after abandonment of the catalyst [8]. Therefore, environmentally friendly metal oxides with outstanding low-temperature activity have currently received considerable attention as potential NH3-SCR catalysts. Although these V-free metal oxide catalysts can reduce NO at approximately 200 °C, less than 80% of the NO conversion rate is achieved for most of the catalysts [9]. Obviously, the current catalytic activity of metal oxides at low temperature is not sufficient when referring to existing emission standards. To date, single-atom catalysts (SACs) as well as double-atom catalysts (DACs) exhibit high catalytic activity and selectivity, which may create a new avenue for NH3-SCR catalysis [10]. Previous studies have indicated that DACs have better preponderance of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) than SACs [11]. Moreover, a Fe-Fe dual-metal embedded in carbon-based substrate material has been successfully synthesized, demonstrating high catalytic activity and satisfactory synergistic effect [12]. Zhang et al. [13] successfully synthesized planar Fe2-N6 structures by coupling isolated Fe1-N4. Interestingly, a number of studies have revealed that the N atoms located in N-doped graphene have a pair of lone electrons, and the transition metal atoms can be anchored by the N atoms, which avoids potential agglomeration of metal atoms and maintain an outstanding stability [14]. Besides, Fe was proven active for O2 activation and NO oxidation according to prior studies [15], thus promoting the “fast SCR” reaction. Based on these unique features of a Fe-Fe double-atom catalyst, we were motivated to study the potential applications of a Fe2-N6 structure for NH3-SCR reaction. In this work, the method of DFT calculations is used. First, the feasible adsorption of different gases (NH3, NO, NO2, O2, H2O, and N2) on the Fe2-N6 catalyst were analyzed. Second, both reaction kinetics and thermodynamics of different steps of the NH3-SCR reaction were investigated. Third, reaction path analysis was performed to determine the dominant path for the NH3-SCR reaction. Finally, microkinetic modelling was conducted to estimate the turnover frequencies (TOFs) to analyze the effects of temperature and pressure on reaction rate. 2 Computational and modeling method DFT calculations were carried out by the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP5.4.4) employing the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional and the projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials [16–18]. To avoid periodic mirror influence, a 5×5 single layer graphene with a 15 Å vacuum layer was built. The spin polarization was set to 2 to eliminate the magnetism of the Fe atoms [19]. Based on our previous studies [20], a 4×4×1 K-point mesh and a 450 eV cutoff energy threshold with 0.02 eV/Å force convergence criteria were sufficient to obtain results of geometric optimization. Apart from this, self-consistent total energy calculation was performed using an 8×8×1 K-point grid and 10−5 eV electron iteration. Van der Waals interaction was considered by using the DFT-D3 correction [20]. The climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [21,22] was adopted to search the transition states roughly. After that, the improved dimer method (IDM) [23] was selected to exactly locate the transition states based on the results generated from CI-NEB method with 0.05 eV/Å force convergence standard [24]. In addition, the precision of transition states was verified by the calculation of vibration frequency with a limited displacement of ±0.02 Å [25]. The adsorption energy (E ads) was calculated according to: (1) E ads = E tot − E cat − E gas where E tot, E cat, and E gas are the total energy of the adsorption complex, adsorbent, and gases, respectively. Moreover, a more negative Eads value indicates the a more stable adsorption. The reaction energy barrier (E b) and heat of reaction (ΔE), which can demonstrate the difficulty of reaction and the endothermic and exothermic characteristics of the reaction, were expressed by: (2) E b = E TS − E IS (3) Δ E = E FS − E IS where E IS, E TS, and E FS are the energy of the initial, transition, and final state, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures of the catalysts and adsorption complexes Considering that a Fe2-N6 structure with the two Fe coordinating with six N atoms is one of the most common types in experimental synthesis [26,27], the geometric structure of Fe2-N6 catalyst is two Fe atoms anchored on graphene substrate with six N atoms, as shown in Fig. 1(a) . The strong binding energy (-11.06 eV) also indicates that the substrate can anchor Fe atoms tightly. In view of the complicacy of the NH3-SCR reaction, the adsorption energy of NH3, NO, NO2, O2, and H2O were calculated to further explore the reaction path with results in Fig. 1(b). The energy of co-adsorption of NH3 and NO (-2.23 eV), NH3 and NO2 (-1.85 eV) is greater than that of NH3 alone (-0.03 eV), indicating that the NH3-SCR reaction over the Fe2-N6 catalyst is more possible to take place according to the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. The adsorption energies of NO, NO2, and O2 are -2.33, -2.12, and -1.91 eV, respectively, suggesting a chemical adsorption mode. The theoretical calculation of Leng et al. [28] shows that the adsorption energy of O2 on Fe2-N6 is -1.98 eV, which is basically consistent with our calculation results. On the other hand, the adsorption energies of H2O and N2 are 0.07 and -0.44 eV, respectively, showing that desorption of NH3-SCR products is relatively facile. In addition, the feasibility of adsorbing substances such as H2O and O2 on Fe2-N6 has been experimentally proved in relevant reports [28–30]. 3.2 Reaction path analysis To further investigate the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over the Fe2-N6 catalyst, possible reaction intermediates and products were firstly considered via different adsorption structures. The energy barriers of different reaction paths were compared to determine the dominant reaction path of NH3-SCR. All structures of NH3-SCR reaction from the various paths are showed in Fig. 2 . Relatively, the possible elementary reaction steps are listed in Table 1 , and the energy profiles for reaction relative paths are showed in Figs. S1–S6. For Path 1 (as shown in Figs. 2 and S1), the gaseous NH3 firstly adsorbs on the surface of Fe2-N6 catalyst with an adsorption energy of -0.03 eV. The NH2 fragment is observed via the NH3 dehydrogenation with an energy barrier of 0.93 eV. Subsequently, the NH2 fragment reacts with the gas-phase NO spontaneously with heat of reaction -0.55 eV to generate the NH2NO, which is similar to the generation of NH2NO species on Mn/γ-Al2O3 [31] and Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst [32]. The NH2NO* species then dissociates into N2 and H2O with a relatively high energy barrier of 2.27 eV via H stripping. The decomposition reaction is exothermic with a reaction heat of -2.63 eV, stimulating the final desorption of N2. Different from Path 1, the gaseous NH3 and NO simultaneously adsorb on the surface of Fe2-N6 catalyst with a high adsorption energy of -2.23 eV in Path 2 (as shown in Figs. 2 and S2). NH3* decomposes to a NH2* fragment and the H atom which shifts to a C atom with an energy barrier of 2.09 eV, indicating that the catalytic activity of the C atom is lower than that of the Fe atom in terms of NH3 dehydrogenation. Thereafter, NO* combines with NH2* to form NH2NO species through the N-N coupling reaction, which is similar to the formation reaction of NH2NO over the CeO2/TiO2 catalyst [33] and Cu-exchanged CHA zeolite [34]. This elementary reaction path is activated by 0.35 eV, and the release of heat (-0.11 eV) promotes the subsequent reaction. Finally, the NH2NO species resolves into N2 and H2O with an energy barrier of 1.94 eV, slightly lower that of Path 1. As mentioned above, NO2 has a vital role in “fast SCR” reaction, which can promote the NH3-SCR reaction. For Path 3 (as shown in Figs. 2 and S3), gaseous NH3 and NO2 adsorb on the surface of Fe2-N6 catalyst simultaneously, with a large adsorption energy of -1.85 eV. The O atom of NO2 strips two H atoms of NH3 to generate the free H2O with an energy barrier of 0.67 eV, in agreement with the in situ DRIFTs experiments by Hu et al. [35], indicating that the monodentate nitrites (NO2*) can react with NH3. Thereafter, NH* interacts with NO* to form the NHNO* species through a N-N coupling reaction with an energy barrier of 0.35 eV, and the NHNO* intermediate (IM9) reacts with gaseous NO* spontaneously to form N2H* and NO2*. Finally, the dehydrogenation reaction of N2H* is observed via the transition state (TS9) with an energy barrier of 0.61 eV. For Path 4 (as shown in Figs. 2 and S4), gaseous NO2 and O2 adsorb on the surface of Fe2-N6 catalyst simultaneously with a high adsorption energy of -3.16 eV. The formation of NO2 is realized via the fracture of O-O bond spontaneously. Thereafter, the NO2* desorbs from the Fe2-N6 catalyst with a desorption energy of 1.42 eV, and the NH3* adsorbs on the Fe2-N6 catalyst with an adsorption energy of 0.3 eV to proceed further reactions. An H atom from NH3* are extracted by the resulting O* with an energy barrier of 0.84 eV to generate the NH2 fragment and OH*. NH2 fragment continues to interact with OH* to form the NH fragment and H2O with an energy barrier of 1.84 eV. Subsequently, the second gaseous NO* adsorbs on the Fe2-N6 catalyst with an adsorption energy of -1.39 V, and the NH fragment then combines with NO* to form NHNO* species via the transition state (TS13) with an energy barrier of 1.22 eV. Following the same procedure as described above, the third gaseous NO attacks NHNO to form N2H* and NO2*, and the breakage of N-H bond is observed via the transition state (TS9) with energy barrier 0.61 eV. Currently, the discovery of HONO intermediates by various methods (e.g., transient response methods, chemical capture techniques, and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR)) in NH3-SCR reaction experiments has been widely reported [36–39]. To achieve the cycle of the NH3-SCR reaction, the resulting H atom reacts with the NO2* to form the HONO species with energy barriers of 1.00 and 2.26 eV in Path 5 and Path 6 (as shown in Figs. 2, S5, and S6), respectively. Subsequently, the gaseous NH3 reacts with the HONO* species forming the NH2NO* species with an energy barrier of 1.36 eV. Finally, the NH2NO* species resolves into N2 and H2O via the transition states (TS16 and TS17) with energy barriers of 1.36 and 0.41 eV, severally, which is similar to the reaction process over Cu-CHA [40]. To intuitively describe the reaction paths which drive the NH3-SCR reaction, the reaction scheme is shown in Fig. 3 . The NH3-SCR reaction on the Fe2-N6 catalyst includes four possible paths, and the energy barriers of the rate-determining step (RDS) for these paths are 2.27, 2.09, 1.00, and 2.40 eV, respectively, suggesting that Path 3 is the dominant reaction path of the NH3-SCR reaction over the Fe2-N6 catalyst. In the catalytic cycle of Path 3 (see Fig. 4 ), there are two reaction steps, consisting of the “fast SCR” reaction and HONO* formation, and the latter step is the RDS of the reaction. In addition, we further considered the possibility of generating N2O under the initial adsorption configuration of Path 3. We calculated the relevant paths and found that a high energy barrier of 1.35 eV will be generated during the generation of N2O, which will hinder the generation of N2O (see Figs. S7 and S8). Therefore, we believe that the fast NH3-SCR reaction on Fe2-N6 is more likely to generate N2 rather than N2O. At the same time, given that SO2 is an important constituent of the flue gas of coal-fired power plants, there is a risk of reducing catalyst resistance to SO2. We considered the effect of SO2 on Fe2-N6 from the perspective of competitive adsorption. Path 3 is the dominant reaction path of NH3-SCR reaction on Fe2-N6 catalyst, and the competitive adsorption between its preadsorbate (NH3+NO2) and SO2 will affect the resistance of the catalyst. Surprisingly, the adsorption energy of co-adsorption of NH3 and NO2 (-1.85 eV) on Fe2-N6 is significantly larger than that of SO2 (-1.50 eV). This means that the preadsorbate (NH3+NO2) of Path 3 will preferentially occupy the reaction site, thereby avoiding the reduction of catalyst resistance caused by the poisoning of SO2. To further evaluate the performance of Fe2-N6 catalyst, the energy barriers of the RDS for the NH3-SCR reaction was compared with commonly used catalysts in Table 2 . The lower energy barrier of the Fe2-N6 catalyst than other SCR catalysts indicates that the Fe2-N6 catalyst can be selected as a candidate for the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.3 Microkinetic modeling To appraise the catalyst activity and investigate the reaction mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction, the TOFs calculated by the CatMAP software [48] were used to estimate the reaction rates with two descriptors, temperature (T) and the logarithm of pressure (logP), as displayed in Fig. 5 . The high and low TOFs are marked with yellow and blue, separately. Compared with other three paths, Path 3 exhibits higher TOFs with a broad area in the descriptor space, which is compared to the lower energy barrier of the RDS in Path 3 than that of other three paths. Meanwhile, the best operation temperature window of Path 3 is 300–500 K, indicating that the Fe2-N6 catalyst has the potential to become a low-temperature catalyst because of its high low-temperature catalytic activity. The co-adsorption coverage of NH3 and NO, NH3 and NO2 outclass NH3 adsorption (Fig. S9), corresponding with the higher adsorption energy of co-adsorption than individual adsorption. Additionally, the higher O* coverage for Path 4 is related to the stronger adsorption energy of the residual O atom (-1.73 eV), indicating that the step of removing the residual O atom is the RDS in Path 4, which is compared with the previous path analysis. 4 Conclusions Based on the preceding systematic theoretical research, the adsorption behavior of various gases, the catalytic mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction, and the corresponding TOFs as the function of temperature and pressure were analyzed based on spin-polarized DFT calculations. We found that the co-adorption mode of various gases is significantly more favourable than the individual adsorption, suggesting that the NH3-SCR reaction on the Fe2-N6 catalyst is more likely to take place in line with the L-H mechanism. Four possible reaction paths were investigated for the NH3-SCR reaction, of which the “fast SCR” reaction is the dominant path of NH3-SCR reaction. The RDS of the NH3-SCR reaction is HONO formation with an energy barrier of 1.00 eV, significantly lower than that of other SCR catalysts. In addition, the Fe2-N6 catalyst exhibits outstanding low-temperature activity in the temperature window from 300 to 500 K. Based on the theoretical results, Fe2-N6 catalyst is a potentially promising and environmentally friendly catalyst with a high low-temperature catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Theoretically designing a catalyst with high catalytic activity for ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) reaction at low temperature to guide the subsequent experimental synthesis, which is of great significance for controlling the emission of NO x . Herein, we examine for the first time Fe2-N6 catalysts as candidates for this application at a theoretical level. The adsorption behavior of various gases, catalytic mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction, and turnover frequency were analyzed using density functional theory calculations (DFT) and microkinetic modeling. We found that a “fast SCR” reaction is the dominant path of the NH3-SCR reaction. The energy barrier for the rate-determining step (HONO formation) is 1.00 eV, much lower than that of other SCR catalysts. In addition, the Fe2-N6 catalyst exhibits outstanding low-temperature activities in the temperature window from 300 to 500 K.
coredata.dc:title: A novel low-temperature Fe-Fe double-atom catalyst for a “fast SCR” reaction
